messages.message: It sometimes feels a little "aggressive" to be saving and running custom code as soon as a user clicks outside of the code editor. Is this behavior that we want? cc: @Serena + @danny.lan + @Natasha
what is the behavior that you would prefer? do you expect the code to be run only when you click “Run code”?
Yeah that was my initial reaction - with some indicator that the result is outdated when code is changed (we do something similar for cleans)

There are some technical constraints here

I agree it would be ideal to show that the result is outdated when the code is changed. We previously did exactly this, but this led to severe performance issues (https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/EPD-2042) that made the UI super slow whenever you made any change to the code editor.

To avoid the performance issues, we cannot re-render the entire results table (ie show “Outdated” next to each cell under “Final result” / “Validation result”) when the code is changed.

As an alternative, we could show “Outdated” at a higher level (ex: show “Outdated” next to the “Final result” / “Validation result” column name) - would that be clear enough?
Yeah I think that would be preferred to this current behavior but glad to get more opinions cc: @hannah + @Bastiane

Btw to clarify, we’re discussing 2 changes
1. showing “Outdated” somewhere that doesn’t cause the frontend to be super slow (ex: next to the “Final result” / “Validation result” column name)
2. running the custom function only in the following cases
    a. when the user clicks “run code”
    b. when the user exits the custom function editor by clicking “X”
is my summary of 2 correct? @Kaustubh (KD)

Yeah and by 2b. do you meaning clicking out of the code editor or do you mean clicking on the `x`? I actually think running should only be done when the user clicks on run. Otherwise the outdated communicates that this is a mismatch in the result displayed with the logic which has changed

for 2b, i meant clicking the “X” - i clarified my original message

after clicking the “X”, we’ll be showing either the field editor or the validation editor
• in the field editor, it may be confusing for the user to find the right button to click to run the custom function
    ◦ there may be a lot of refinement lines, for example, and they would need to scroll to find the one with an outdated result
• in the validation editor, there’s no run button, so we have to automatically run the validation custom function
Hmm I see. also cc: @Natasha / @Jianqi Xing / @alagu here for design thoughts
